newsitem.title: USA: Nebraska winter wheat reported in need of moisture.
newsitem.headline: Nebraska winter wheat reported in need of moisture.

text.p: Hard red winter wheat in Nebraska came through the winter in better condition than last year but moisture is needed to aid development, according to the state's agricultural statistics service.
The crop as of Sunday, was rated three percent excellent, 53 percent good, 38 percent fair and six percent poor.
"Moisture supplies in the southwest and parts of the Panhandle were short. Additional moisture is also needed to aid germination of spring planted crops," the report said.
Topsoil moisture was rated six percent very short, 34 percent short, 55 percent adequate and five percent surplus.
Oats seeding was 18 percent complete, ahead of last year's 10 percent and a five-year average of 14 percent.
"Seeding was least advanced in the northeast part of the state due to wet field conditions," the report said, noting one percent of the crop had emerged.
Pasture and range conditions were rated three percent poor, 28 percent fair, 67 percent good and two percent excellent.
